1401302378|4.0|While some try to dismiss the message of this book as merely an article about a statistical graph, I found the ideas in the book interesting and some of them powerful.  There are many books on the Internet and what it can do to open mass customization, how it impacts the economic doctrine of the allocation of scarce resources (although the concept is almost universally misunderstood in these discussions), the need to open a digital front to your customers, and so forth.  This book could be lumped into this group and stuck on the shelf next to them, but I think that would be a mistake.<br /><br />This book deals in specifics about what is happening with real businesses rather than with what could happen.  Chris Anderson shows us how the small volume items can generate significant aggregate sales.  Even the seemingly vast selection offered by the big box stores and Wal-Mart ends up being only the surface of what is actually available when one is not limited by shelf space and transportation costs.<br /><br />I think the great examples the book offers are Wal-Mart and Rhapsody.  Wal-Mart sells something like 20% of all music sales in America, yet it carries only 4,500 titles (Amazon.com offers 800,000 music titles).  Of the 30,000 new albums released each year, Wal-Mart carries only 750 (pages 155-156).  Yet 40% of Rhapsody's sales come from titles not available in retail stores.  These are titles that individually only sell a few times each, but in aggregate become a huge revenue generator.  In the digital world, it costs almost nothing to keep these titles in inventory, but providing them a physical presence in thousands of stores cannot be justified.<br /><br />Some retailers are tapping into this effect by offering a much wider variety of products online than are available in even their largest stores.  Manufacturers are also offering products online that are not available through any retailer.  Anderson reminds us that when you go to your local store to buy a Kitchen Aid mixer you will likely find only three colors - white, black, and something else (he also shares why retailers choose this selection).  If you go to the Kitchen Aid website you can choose among fifty colors.  Similarly, Lego has a specialized set of offerings for its hobbyist force that are not available anywhere else.<br /><br />The author also discusses the varying studies that seem to say contrary things about customers and choice.  It turns out that customers show their preference for lots of choice over and over again.  But successful offerings of choice also have to provide help for the consumer to find what he or she is looking for.  It involves search, product information, even samples.<br /><br />The last chapter offers nine rules for functioning in the world of the Long Tail.  I think the book is quite interesting and appropriately sized for the insights it offers.  There are some helpful charts and graphs, as well.  The hard part is thinking through the implications of this reality for your business and for your competitive situation.<br /><br />Good strategizing!a Kitchen Aid mixer you will likely find only three colors - white, black, and something else (he also shares why retailers choose this selection).  If you go to the Kitchen Aid website you can choose among fifty colors.  Similarly, Lego has a specialized set of offerings for its hobbyist force that are not available anywhere else. <br /> <br />The author also discusses the varying studies that seem to say contrary things about customers and choice.  It turns out that customers show their preference for lots of choice over and over again.  But successful offerings of choice also have to provide help for the consumer to find what he or she is looking for.  It involves search, product information, even samples.   <br /> <br />The last chapter offers nine rules for functioning in the world of the Long Tail.  I think the book is quite interesting and appropriately sized for the insights it offers.  There are some helpful charts and graphs, as well.  The hard part is thinking through the implications of this reality for your business and for your competitive situation.   <br /> <br />Good strategizing!
B000E15JY2|5.0|Dr. Victor Frankl was a successful psychiatrist in Vienna, Austria with a wife and child before World War II. As a Jewish family, his wife and child were murdered in the Holocaust but he survived by being a doctor in the camps. While most of us would probably curse the German Nazis who killed his wife and child. He uses his suffering and examines how suffering can help better a person's life in this book. He doesn't recommend everbody suffers but his voice is one of reason, kindness, forgiveness, and gentleness. He describes the horrors of World War II and the camps. He also gives a detailed account even criticizing his fellow Jewish prisoners who play favorites with prison guards. Not all the Germans were cruel and mean, one even got medicine for them and they paid by trying to save his life after the war. It's a war and people were both inhumane and humane to each other despite their ethnic differences.
6305263248|4.0|The entirety of Ronin involves a narrative that exists on just the other side of \\"real\\" -- competing political factions vying for a metal briefcase whose contents are a perpetual mystery.  The \\"good guys\\", if they can be called that, are a small coterie of mercenaries who were presumably relieved of their legitimate jobs with the winding down of the Cold War.  They're hired by an Irish faction operating in Paris represented by Dierdre (Natascha McElhone) via the unseen \\"man in a wheelchair\\", an agent for these \\"ronin for hire\\".  (Ronin were the ancient Japanese samurai who were cast out of their fiefdom for failure to adequately protect their liege, essentially becoming free-agent wandering warriors.)  They are of different nationalities, backgrounds, and possess different talents.  Sam the American (Robert De Niro), develops a kinship with the Frenchman Vincent (Jean Reno) and becomes de facto leader of the band. After a planned exchange for the briefcase goes awry, they devise and execute a violent ambush in the streets of Nice to get the briefcase and take out its current possessors.  When Plan B fails, the fun begins.    Through double-cross and intrigue, the briefcase remains elusive.  Plans are revised, payments are \\"re-negotiated\\", and hunters become hunted to the point of making for a five-sided chase. Even the Russians become involved, including an unassuming touring figure skater played by Katarina Witt.  It all sounds very contrived and even trite to a degree, but attached to this story are some of the fiercest street gunfights and most exciting car chases any action film fan could hope for!  Many innocents (and vehicles!) become victims, but these adversaries in espionage openly shop, dine, and roam the streets as if they're tourists and the French authorities are on some far-off planet. Through death and deceit, De Niro and Reno eventually form a buddy-buddy duo to exact revenge and extract payment.  \\"Old friends from high school\\" appear out of nowhereto aid in the alternating pursuits and escapes. Ironically, actor Michael Lonsdale, who was so great as the assassin-pursuing French Inspector Lebel in Fred Zinneman's The Day of the Jackal, does a marvelous turn as one of these convenient \\"friends\\", providing refuge to the pair for some do-it-yourself surgery.  While the hunt and chase is on, viewers are also treated to some marvelous French town and cityscapes, including the ancient Roman amphitheater at Arles and the traffic tunnels of Paris.    Ronin is a film for those who can suspend their sense of logic to allow themselves to be taken for the ride.  Thankfully, nothing devolves into outright camp a la James Bond. The danger of this approach is that for the film to be effective, the viewer must be held in thrall by these contrived characters and their actions to the point of being oblivious to their real-world consequences. De Niro, director John Frankenheimer and company manage to pull it off.  Because of its sheer unabashed cinematicism and no-holds-barred direction, Ronin succeeds in pushing this reviewer's grade one star above average when the film's holes could just as easily have let it fall one star below.
0553804677|4.0|THE LIES OF LOCKE LAMORA is a fairly-well-hyped fantasy debut about the charismatic leader of a gang of con artists in a city that does (or tries to do) for renaissance Venice what PERDIDO STREET STATION did for Dickensian London. Overall, I enjoyed it - the prose was technically proficient, the plot hummed along efficiently, the setting was considerably more interesting than the usual plate-mail-and-offal-carts business, and there was a good deal of welcome humor. As debut novels go it's a promising start. <br /> <br />On the other hand, it really doesn't amount to much more than an entertaining confection. The book's apparently been optioned for a movie already, and I can see why: the dialogue's relentlessly effervescent, occasionally stretching credulity past the breaking point (characters have one-liners for every occasion even while collecting broken bones and concussions like trading cards) and the screenplay-friendly three-act structure is too often embarrassingly visible underneath the flesh of the story. <br /> <br />It's difficult to articulate my feelings on books like this. On the one hand, Lynch's technical talent clearly elevates him above the great gormless herd of modern fantasy writers already. And there's no denying that the book is very likeable indeed, while it seems unfair to fault it based only on what it could have been. On the other hand, it's just *too damn safe*. Lynch is going to be a major player in the genre - that much is obvious already - but he has it in him to do something Seriously Good rather than settling for being the next RA Salvatore. But it's not gonna happen until he gets over his fear of failure. PERDIDO had parts that worked and parts that didn't but Mieville wrote his ambition on every page in letters of fire, and the excitement swept me, the reader, away with him. Whereas LOCKE LAMORA felt like Lynch was parceling out his ideas and his talent and calculating every story beat based on whether it would make a good start fora franchise. <br /> <br />In short, it's worth the money, even if you're not big into fantasy - I'm emphatically not, aside from staples like Tolkien, Moorcock, and Martin, and I still enjoyed it. But it's not a *necessary* book.

6305736650|5.0|\\"Casablanca\\" is a landmark film. It's 64 years old and yet most of the dialogue is still quoted today, it's #2 on The American Film Institute's Top 100 (just directly below \\"Citizen Kane\\"), and is a true masterpiece of film. <br />I typically don't watch films from this era, I've never seen a film with Humphrey Bogart or Ingrid Bergman; This is not the most entertaining of several of my favorite movies that are on AFI's list below this film, nor is this the second most entertaining film ever made...But it is an important one; But that's not why I'm giving it 5 stars. The biggest thing I look for when reviewing a film in the quality of entertainment; I don't care how important the movie is, if it's kind of dull I won't rank it that high. This film is a beautiful and entertaining film; The cinematography/lighting is beautiful, the dialogue is beautiful, the acting is wonderful, the film is incredibly influential. Anyway; The movie is set against the backdrop of World War II in Casablanca and takes place mostly in a gambling/gin joint owned by Rick Blaine (Bogart), a distant kind of guy who \\"doesn't stick his neck out for anybody\\" and seems to find no enjoyment in life. He runs his gin joint and that's it. After some transfer papers are stolen (and are subsequently being looked for by the Germans) and are given to Rick, the man who gives them to him is arrested shortly after and Rick awaits the gentlemen who will pick them up. That man is Victor Laszlo, who is famous for having spent a year in a concentration camp and escaping; Also along with Laszlo is his beautiful wife Isla Lund (Bergman), who is tied to Rick's past. Back in 1942, the film won 3 Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Screenplay. How it lost (although I'm not sure if it was even nominated) Best Cinematography and Best Actor is beyond me. As I said, I've never seen a film with Humphrey Bogart before but the man is an amazing actor. He has this way of speaking and a way of moving thatreally sucks you in. Some of the dialogue (although it is great) wouldn't work coming out of other actors mouths; Here, it's perfectly fine. \\"Here's looking at you kid\\" and \\"I believe this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship\\" is classic movie dialogue that we will no doubt here for a much longer time. This isn't a movie the whole family can rent for a night of Saturday night entertainment; But for film buffs and classic film mongers, this is a film you can't miss. <br /> <br />GRADE: A <br />

B0002I10RW|2.0|I am not sure where to start with this movie, or this persuasive visually essay. After all, that is what it is. Anyone who states this movie is entire fact, despite political stripe, is really not being honest with himself or herself. Many of Michael Moore's arguments and positions on topics really follow a \\"1 + 1 = 3\\" formula. For instance Fahrenheit 9/11 opens with the Bush/Gore 2000 election. How different news channels weren't displaying solidarity with the results of the election. Then the film states how Bush stole Florida from Gore. How did Bush do this? Well his brother Jeb was the governor at the time, which is how! Now I am not saying that isn't shady, and I was living in Florida and voted in that election, I recall how crazy that entire process was. But you know how this entire situation could have been avoided? If Al Gore won Tennessee (his home state) and Arkansas (President Bill Clinton's home state, after all Gore worked with him for eight years). Had Gore won these states, he wouldn't have had to worry about Florida! Nevertheless, jolly old Michael Moore omits these types of facts throughout the entire film. I know many people on the right side of the fence were upset with this movie and feel it shouldn't have been made. My response to that notion is \\"If you are that upset GOP, make your own movie.\\"<br /><br />As for President George W. Bush, I have a question. Is he the dumbest kid on the street or is he the devil himself? Because I find myself getting really confused, I am not sure how he can be both. I imagine someone who is really evil to be very intelligent, not to be stupid. Consequently, President Bush seems to be both, as ominous as Hitler, but as dumb as Porky Pig. I am confused, but I think that is the ruse behind Moore's mix message in this movie.<br /><br />I want it to be understood I don't think Bush is the brightest crayon in the box, but I don't think the fault of the world is his pratfall. It just isn't one person who makes decisions in government; any college level course will explain that information to you. There are many shadowy and dark figures in American politics that are both Republican and Democrat. These factors fall into every element of contemporary America.<br /><br />As for 9/11 itself, what a terrible thing to happen to any country, the fact it happened in New York City was unspeakable. I am able to say I had been to the WTC before and after the attack. Seeing the aftermath was quite moving, to think one of the greatest cites in the world became a target of hate and pain. As for the human-interest story about the solider that was killed and his mother coping, was touching. However, what about every soldier's family who had to deal with a death related to the War on Terror? Not just in this current war, but in every war that was ever fought? The bloody shirt technique was both moving and a low blow all at the same time. As I write this, I feel conflicted, but please remember that movie making has the magic of editing. Was that mother's pain fake, no? Was her son not a hero, of course he was. But every war has a casualty, which is why it is war. And for every mother, who is upset her son/daughter is involved with this war, there is another mother/father who is pleased her son/daughter is defending the United States. I think Michael Moore should have selected more than one family for his visually diatribe, what do you think?<br /><br />I suppose I understand Moore's plan, blame people here in the United States because after all if Al Gore were president we wouldn't have terrorists, right? If Al Gore were president we would all have better public schools, lower taxes and no crime, right? Finally, if Al Gore were president there would be no plot against the United States, United Kingdom and other countries, in regards to blowing up public airlines? Right? Remember that the WTC was attacked back in 1993 by terrorists, when Bill Clinton was President. Just some food for thought.<br /><br />In modern times, we as a country should stand together and be a democracy, blaming each other and falling apart is giving terrorists what they want. Especially with all the horror going on with issues around the world today. My greatest concern is this; once Bush is out of office are we still going to be blaming him? Or are we going to be moving forward? There are still some hard core GOP members who still hate Bill Clinton for things that are wrong in this country. Come on people.<br /><br />In conclusion, the moral of the story is don't believe everything you see on TV. This movie should be an inspiration for people everywhere to tap into their critical thinking skills. The problem with this country isn't Bush, Michael Moore or the War in the Middle East. It is that fact that more people are involved in voting for the next American Idol, not the next American President.ht. <br /> <br />In modern times, we as a country should stand together and be a democracy, blaming each other and falling apart is giving terrorists what they want. 0812550706|5.0|The main characters in the story Ender's game are Ender, Peter and Valentine. The basic plot for Ender is to beat the problems given to him by the teachers, while Peter and Valentine try to spread the \\"truth\\" by using the Internet. The setting is at a \\"Battle School\\" in space. A problem Ender gets into is bullying. People bully him around because he's small, but he learns how to deal with it, sometimes in a violent way. <br /> <br />This book will teach you about intellectual perseverance, to keep trying. When I saw this book, it looked like a long book that had little promises. After I started reading it, I couldn't put the book down. It felt like I was Ender, facing all of his challenges. It told me that everyone would be human, in just about any situation, like when Ender hurt the boy bullying him, just so he'd stop taunting him. I learned that mostly everyone has someone they rely on, like how Ender relied on Valentine, but when that's taken away you will have to learn to rely on yourself. The length of paragraph and chapters is not just full of extra words and texts, but it presents wondrous pictures, especially about the Battle School since that's where most of the story takes place. I would recommend reading this book even if you aren't interested in science fiction. It will take your imagination and expand it in ways you never thought of.
B00028HBKM|4.0|What the world needs now is one more opinion on Mel Gibson's \\"The Passion of the Christ\\", right?<br /><br />I am adding mine because some have asked for it. But, as has been noted hundreds of times over, the movie itself is only part of the experience that is \\"The Passion.\\" At this point the publicity, the prevailing Church attitude toward movies and celebrity, the accusations of bigotry, the accuracy and theology of the film, and the personality of Mel Gibson are of one cloth with it. So this will be a longer than usual review. It's taken me six months to write it.<br /><br />MEL - As Seattle film critic William Arnold says, \\"I've been reading a lot about how Gibson has a martyr complex. I think that's ridiculous. Gibson is less a would-be martyr than a provocateur. There's something in his nature that delights in being abrasive and politically incorrect...He loves to light up a cigarette in places where it's forbidden.\\"<br /><br />I agree. Mel loves to goad people then gauge their response.<br /><br />Is that what \\"The Passion\\" is about? I honestly don't think so. Mel seems to have put an earnest effort into realizing his conception of Christ on film.<br /><br />MARKETING - Of far greater concern to me was the rush of devout, well-meaning Christians to this movie's defense and its propogation - before it was even released. Gibson's passionate creation of this film was an overt mainstream validation that many orthodox Christians had been starving for. His Icon production company leapt on this fact and created an enormous grass-roots marketing campaign that was wildly inexpensive considering the saturation it achieved. With volunteers fanning out across the suburbs bearing posters and leaflets and churches eagerly buying billboards that had Mel's name next to the name of their church, it was probably the biggest publicity coup of the decade.<br /><br />ANTI-SEMITIC? - In my humble Gentile opinion? Not that I can see. Apart from the Romans, virtually every character in the story is a Jew. Besides the disciples, there are good and kind Jews depicted throughout. The Sanhedrin, the religious and civic governing elders, are even conflicted over whether to put Jesus to death, with several arguing against it. Their initiation of His crucifixion to eliminate a religious threat is not a Gibsonian invention, however. It is written in all the gospels. If this film reflects poorly on anyone, it's the Italians. The maddeningly sadistic scourging and crucifixion are their doing. Which brings me to the next point.<br /><br />SHOCKING - One alarming facet of the evangelical reverence of this movie is the prima facie acceptance of the blanching gore and violence that permeate the \\"The Passion.\\" Most viewers have to shut their eyes at points throughout the film and a few have even left to be sick. Yet some parents (who would never allow their kids to hear a swear word or a discussion on married sex!) took their younger children to it because \\"they need to see what Jesus went through.\\" This simply floors me. Yes, as a Christian I believe Christ's death and resurrection are the preeminent events in human history and the deciding factor in every human life. But Little Timmy is still wrapping his head around Sunday school stories about the sweet, smiling cartoon Jesus who coddles lambs in his coloring books being killed because Timmy stole his friend's Hot Wheel car and lied about breaking Mom's favorite vase. Although it is true, the concept alone is often confusing and worrisome to them as it is.<br /><br />Am I objecting to an honest and unflinching portrayal of Christ's suffering on my behalf? If it evokes repentence, gratitude, and adoration, then not in the least. But if it lingers on it salaciously, then yes. I think that - by and large - this film accomplishes the positive results. But it sometimes veers into the gratuitous, too.<br /><br />I often compare \\"The Passion\\" to \\"Saving Private Ryan.\\" That film and its chilling brutality were both an awe-stricken acknowledgement of the sacrifice of the veterans of World War II and a visceral repellant against war itself. It was shocking but vitally necessary. So it can be argued for \\"The Passion of the Christ.\\" Jesus died a vicious death to rescue all of us. We should be reminded of that and be repelled from taking its cause - our sin - lightly.<br /><br />But young children should not watch either movie. Period. And I hope never to watch them (along with \\"Schindler's List\\") more than a few times in my life. Any more than that and I might become desensitized to them and thus their central purpose. And that would be unwise.<br /><br />ACCURACY - It gets much of the biblically supported material right. BTW, the dream of Pilate's wife IS in the Bible (Matt. 27:19). The merely interpretive parts are often astonishlingly moving, even if they didn't necessarily happen that way.<br /><br />How does it fare theologically? Depends on your theology. \\"The Passion\\" makes it clear that Christ died to save the world. The most gutwrenching scene for me was when Jesus stumbles under the cross and tells Mary, \\"See, mother. I'm making everything new.\\"<br /><br />Those who complain that Gibson has minimized Jesus' message of \\"peace, love, and understanding\\" in favor of sin and death need to 1) See the movie again and 2) Read the Scriptures again. If Christ's was not the ultimate example of nonviolent conviction, I don't know what is. As the Son of God, He could have struck His executioners dead at any point along the way. But Jesus was not a first-century hippie, either. He spoke more of a literal hell and of complete obedience to God than anyone else in the New Testament. And, honestly, the last twelve hours of His life weren't very conducive to preaching on diversity.<br /><br />This is a decidedly Catholic film. For example, the Stations of the Cross (a sequence of passion events enumerated in the Catholic prayers of the same name) are dutifully enacted, even at risk of creating cinematic redundancy. Mary seems able to locate Jesus through solid rock floors by \\"sensing\\" Him. But the scenes and events based on the extrabiblical writings of mystics and on later traditions that are regarded as history by some Catholics are alternately distracting and disturbing.<br /><br />BUT IS IT A GOOD MOVIE? - There may be no objective way for me to watch this. I suppose the only way I can answer the question is by rephrasing: Was it a successful movie? Did it have it's intended effect on the audience?<br /><br />Yes. And then some.ns of World War II and a visceral repellant against war itself. It was shocking but vitally necessary. So it can be argued for \\"The Passion of the Christ.\\" Jesus died a vicious death to rescue all of us. We should be reminded of that and be repelled from taking its cause - our sin - lightly.     But young children should not watch either movie. Period. And I hope never to watch them (along with \\"Schindler's List\\") more than a few times in my life. Any more than that and I might become desensitized to them and thus their central purpose. And that would be unwise.     ACCURACY - It gets much of the biblically supported material right. BTW, the dream of Pilate's wife IS in the Bible (Matt. 27:19). The merely interpretive parts are often astonishlingly moving, even if they didn't necessarily happen that way.    How does it fare theologically? Depends on your theology. \\"The Passion\\" makes it clear that Christ died to save the world. The most gutwrenching scene for me was when Jesus stumbles under the cross and tells Mary, \\"See, mother. I'm making everything new.\\"     Those who complain that Gibson has minimized Jesus' message of \\"peace, love, and understanding\\" in favor of sin and death need to 1) See the movie again and 2) Read the Scriptures again. If Christ's was not the ultimate example of nonviolent conviction, I don't know what is. As the Son of God, He could have struck His executioners dead at any point along the way. But Jesus was not a first-century hippie, either. He spoke more of a literal hell and of complete obedience to God than anyone else in the New Testament. And, honestly, the last twelve hours of His life weren't very conducive to preaching on diversity.     This is a decidedly Catholic film. For example, the Stations of the Cross (a sequence of passion events enumerated in the Catholic prayers of the same name) are dutifully enacted, even at risk of creating cinematic redundancy. Mary seems able to locate Jesus through solid rock floors by \\"sensing\\"Him. But the scenes and events based on the extrabiblical writings of mystics and on later traditions that are regarded as history by some Catholics are alternately distracting and disturbing.    BUT IS IT A GOOD MOVIE? - There may be no objective way for me to watch this. I suppose the only way I can answer the question is by rephrasing: Was it a successful movie? Did it have it's intended effect on the audience?     Yes. And then some.

B000E5N62U|4.0|Donald Fagan is without question one of the great Master rock/jazz composers of the modern era. Often combining rock and jazz, the tunes on this CD are full-bodied, loaded with story and pleasing to the ear. You want to listen to them over and over again.  'Morph The Cat' opens this latest Fagen solo effort and you immediately are pulled into the driving bass followed by superb vocal arrangements and guitar work. The 'H Gang' is another terrific song with great lyrics and a rythym that moves you along. 'What I Do' is a medium tempo song about Donald talking to the ghost of Ray Charles. 'Brite Nightgown' is somewhat comical in it's presentation but is actually a trilogy of tales about a run-in with the Grim Reaper. You will love the vocals shared on this between Fagan and the lovely and talented Carolyn Leonhart, a regular vocalist with the Steely Dan team. 'The Great Pagoda Of Funn' is slower paced ballad about lovers pushing troubles away. Nice tune! 'Security Joan' is a 60's style rock song about a meeting with a female airport security guard and the love the follows. 'The Night Belongs to Mona' is an excellent piece of writing about a woman's night only lifestyle due possibly to post 9/11 fears. 'Mary Shut The Garden Door' is a fantastic arrangement with jazzy-Latin rythym and haunting vocal work, about  the take-over of the government by thugs (a well-placed poke at the current administration). There is not a single weak point on this CD. Donald Fagen's work here is diversified, carefully thought out and well placed. He never misses. And above all remember, You Can't Fight With the Fella in the Bright Night Gown!

B00006879E|5.0|I'm a confirmed baby-boomer and usually buy only 60's and 70's music, but after I got XM radio in my new pickup truck I started hearing a few newer songs that I liked and almost all of them were sung by \\"Maroon 5\\".  I didn't even know who they were.  I do now!  \\"Songs About Jane\\" is a great CD for playing over and over on a long drive or a boring commute.  It will keep your foot tapping and (weather permitting) you can roll down the window and slap the side of your door!  There are a couple of soft jazzy ballads mixed in to get your heart rate back down to normal.  The beat is usually relentless, the chord and key shifts beautiful and often unexpected, and the high vocal harmonies (wish there were more of them) are as precise as Lennon-McCartney or Heart.  Each week, a different song from this CD will find its way into your subconcious and refuse to leave!  OK, so a few of the songs do have a \\"Motown\\" aura to them...after Motown got mowed-down by rap, we need someone to revive the original Motown sound anyway.  Way to go Maroon 5 -- there is some hope for the music of the \\"X\\" (or is it \\"Y\\"?) generation!
B000G759LW|4.0|Mrs. Bratman's double-disc jazz throwback album is one of the freshest sounding albums to be released this year. With her mile-high pipes and chameleon-esque style, it's no wonder Christina is probably the only pop-culture icon that could pull off such a feat. Although it isn't perfect, the album does exceed this reviewer's expectations.<br /><br />Disc One of 'Back to Basics' is the modern take on jazz. Christina looks to hip-hop producers and heavy samples to make the first half of the album sound fresh and radio-friendly.<br /><br />Lead single \\"Ain't No Other Man\\" is probably one of the strongest tracks on the album. With it's heavy horns, sampled vocals, and tight-cut, fast-paced beats, it's no wonder it's one of the more prominent singles on the radio.<br /><br />Other tracks on the first half, like \\"Slow Down Baby\\" and \\"On Our Way\\" manage to stack-up against \\"Ain't No Other Man\\", and ballads like \\"Oh Mother\\" and the hip-hop R&B-tinged track \\"Understand\\" also stand-out.<br /><br />There is also an interlude on this half called \\"F.U.S.S.\\" that is kinda low-key. The initials of the track stand for \\"F*ck You Scott Storch\\", the hip-hop producer that refused to be a part of the project. But as she says, she 'still got the record out'. Gotta love it when artists call people out like that.<br /><br />But perhaps the strongest point on the first disc is \\"Still Dirrty\\", on which Xtina argues that she's 'still got the nasty in me'. The horn sample is crazy and the beat really swings the hips.<br /><br />Closer \\"Thank You\\" samples her previous hits 'Genie in a Bottle' and 'Can't Hold Us Down', over an old-school groove. It also samples messages from fans and is a very beautiful way to close the album.<br /><br />Disc Two is produced by Linda Perry, the woman responsible for \\"Beautiful\\". This disc is the actual jazz half of the album. Switching into a circus groove and old-time blues, the disc is rather short but very well-done.<br /><br />The intro is Linda Perry inviting you to the 'greatest show on earth' and is followed by a very fun song titled \\"Welcome\\". It's heavy on the orchestration and actually does sound like it could be a part of a circus.<br /><br />The second single to come from the album, according to her latest cover of Rolling Stone, is \\"Candyman\\". A direct rip-off of the \\"Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy\\" with a... erm, twist. Christina gets her nasty on and proves she's \\"Still Dirrty\\". It's almost funny, but more fun than anything else. From having the Candyman making the 'panties drop' to making her 'cherry pop', this song is a raunch-fest that is one of the funnest songs this half of the album.<br /><br />The following song, the swanky tune \\"Nasty Naughty Boy\\" invites a boy to taste the 'sugar below her waist'. Her vocals are beautiful and the music is simple and striking. At this point you realize that Christina is more than capable to pull this album off.<br /><br />\\"I Got Trouble\\" comes next. Although the music is great, it was recorded with cloth over the mic to create a vintage sound. It wants to succeed, but becomes annoying much faster. If it had been recorded more like the previous tracks it would have been great, but it falls flat.<br /><br />The next track \\"Hurt\\" is Aguilera re-calling a love lost. It's beautiful and powerful. This is Christina at her strongest.<br /><br />My favorite track on this half is \\"Save Me From Myself\\". Christina recorded it after knocking back a few and it's beautiful and simple. It's a moving love song.<br /><br />I would probably have given this album 5 stars if it had been shorter... as in one disc. Although none of the material classifies as terrible, some of it is just unnecessary. As the title of my review stated \\"Too Self-Indulgent to Surpass 'Stripped\\". She just gave us a little too much. If it had been skimmed down, she would have had a masterpiece.Linda Perry inviting you to the 'greatest show on earth' and is followed by a very fun song titled \\"Welcome\\". It's heavy on the orchestration and actually does sound like it could be a part of a circus.  <br /> <br />The second single to come from the album, according to her latest cover of Rolling Stone, is \\"Candyman\\". A direct rip-off of the \\"Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy\\" with a... erm, twist. Christina gets her nasty on and proves she's \\"Still Dirrty\\". It's almost funny, but more fun than anything else. From having the Candyman making the 'panties drop' to making her 'cherry pop', this song is a raunch-fest that is one of the funnest songs this half of the album. <br /> <br />The following song, the swanky tune \\"Nasty Naughty Boy\\" invites a boy to taste the 'sugar below her waist'. Her vocals are beautiful and the music is simple and striking. At this point you realize that Christina is more than capable to pull this album off. <br /> <br />\\"I Got Trouble\\" comes next. Although the music is great, it was recorded with cloth over the mic to create a vintage sound. It wants to succeed, but becomes annoying much faster. If it had been recorded more like the previous tracks it would have been great, but it falls flat. <br /> <br />The next track \\"Hurt\\" is Aguilera re-calling a love lost. It's beautiful and powerful. This is Christina at her strongest. <br /> <br />My favorite track on this half is \\"Save Me From Myself\\". Christina recorded it after knocking back a few and it's beautiful and simple. It's a moving love song.  <br /> <br />I would probably have given this album 5 stars if it had been shorter... as in one disc. Although none of the material classifies as terrible, some of it is just unnecessary. As the title of my review stated \\"Too Self-Indulgent to Surpass 'Stripped\\". She just gave us a little too much. If it had been skimmed down, she would have had a masterpiece.

The book is well written, and written by one of my favorite authors, but it does have weaknesses.<br />  The book is very informative about the history of philosophy and the study of ideas by many important philosophers, but at times it seems that your reading out of a school textbook rather than adventurous story. Jostein Gaarder wastes no time in getting the reader's attention at the beginning of the first chapter, but towards the end it seems some parts of the story comes out of place. For example, the folk story characters that Jostein uses to get his point across in the book  at times seems kind of childish and silly. B000G75AE8|4.0|I have to say that compared with other bands out there and compared with other comebacks from thrash bands of the 80's, Slayer demonstrates that have not loose a gram of quality, energy and violence, they return to claim their seat as kings of the genre they invented and definitely a must-have album for this year. You will not find the speed of Reign in Blood, the scary atmosphere of South of Heaven nor the punch of the riffs of Seasons. B000002B35|5.0|****1/2 <br />I agree with the other reviewer who said that this recording of the 1994 Earl's Court performance \\"seems to lack energy at times.\\" It sounds great, don't get me wrong, but the crowd doesn't seem particularly enthusiastic for most of the performance. Yes, they cheer, but I like a live album where you can hear them singing along faintly in the background and where the cheers following the performance of a song reach the same volume or a greater volume than the song itself. This is one of the things that separates a live recording from a studio album, and that energy is somewhat lacking on this CD. I can only conclude that none of the mics were angled towards the audience, but I get the impression that seeing this show live must have been incredible. <br /> <br />That said, Floyd sounds as good as ever on this work. The biggest attraction here is obviously the live performance of the entire \\"Dark Side Of The Moon\\" album, which is utterly fantastic. PULSE is worth owning for this live rendition of the Floyd's masterpiece alone. The rest of the material on here is an added bonus. PULSE includes what I believe is the best-ever recording of \\"Wish You Were Here,\\" but I do think it should have been the last encore rather than the first... but that's just me. In any case, it sounds better than the studio recording, which was fantastic to begin with.  <br /> <br />Floyd fans really can't go wrong here, especially those who enjoy the band's post-Waters work. Those who prefer the Waters-era Floyd the most will want this just for the DSOTM performance. This is a great live CD by any standard, and is well worth picking up.

However, every time I crank this album up, I get this feeling like \\"Man, what have I been listening to the past couple weeks?! Emperor?! Killswitch Engage?!\\" <br />Emperor and KsE are two excellent bands [especially Emperor's final album; it was an absolute masterpiece], but you can hear Slayer in both bands [and every other modern metal band on the planet]. <br />It's always amusing for me to note one thing. I've heard vocalists try to do a hardcore or death metal interpretation of Tom's vox, and it just doesn't fit. B000FVQM2Y|5.0|'Brick' is smart.  It's a twist on the general crime noir, giving it an all too real feel by involving our deteriorating youth.  The majority of this film takes place on school grounds or in mom and pops basement, but it never feels amateur or immature.  This is mostly due to the cast of young actors who play their parts with sincerity and caution, not to appear too 'high-schoolish' while never crossing the line as to appear 'too old for the game' if you know what I mean.  These are the high school students of today. <br /> <br />When Brendan (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) gets a message from his ex-girlfriend Emily (Emilie de Ravin) claiming to need help of some sort he finds himself delving deep into the underground ring of high-school crime, and when Emily shows up dead this leads Brendan to encounter and befriend (sort-of) all sorts of twisted teens, from the 26+ drug king known as The Pin (Lukas Haas) to his impatient strong arm Tug (Noah Fleiss) to the mysterious rich girl Laura (Nora Zehetner) who seems all to eager to help Brendan in his journey to uncover Emily's killer. <br /> <br />Joseph plays Brendan, the loner student who always hangs on the outskirts of trouble, with enough subtlety and lax to make him believable.  You know he wants to help but you get the feeling it's not just because he feels he has too; I think he just knows that he can.  I've been a fan of Joseph's for a while now, favoring his brilliant work in Mysterious Skin over unworthy Oscar nominee Terrance Howard last year, and with 'Brick' Levitt continues to prove his weight in gold.  Meagan Good also turns out a convincing conniving manipulative tramp in the form of Drama Queen Kara, and Mike O'Leary does a great job as Brendan's confidant and friend The Brain. <br /> <br />The script is also a major plus, creating an almost poetic lingo for today's teens, giving the film an interesting perspective and leading to some very interesting conversations.  Since there are a lot of those it's good tohave dialog that grabs you and holds your attention.  Some of the best dialog is shared between Brendan and The Brain, the both of them spitting off line after line fluently and effortlessly.  As far as plot boilers go 'Brick' pulls no punches and it delivers 100% giving us something new, fresh and unique, something that if done wrong could have been disastrous, but with a brilliant script and acting to boot 'Brick' easily becomes one of the most fascinating and memorable thrillers in the recent years.

B000G759LW|5.0|Nobody has ever doubted whether or not Christina Aguilera had the vocal chords to succeed in the industry. From the moment she set foot in the industry, we've all been awakened by a voice that is simply so intricate, unique, and refreshing. A truly gifted talent, the only question surrounding this one-of-a-kind perfromer has been whether or not she would ever put together that timeless classic that would thump the eardrums of listeners forever. Well, fast forward a near decade and the times have come full circle, Back To Basics is undoubtedly an instant classic. <br />   For her follow-up to the very impressive sophomore album Stripped, Christina Aguilera enlisted the help of two of the industry's most creative songwriters/producers, DJ Premiere and Linda Perry, to create the unique sound of the double-disc compilation. DJ Premiere does an admirable job fusing the sound of the 20's, 30's, & 40's (mostly through samples) with the drums, synth, and bass-heavy vibes of our modern sound, ultimately bringing about an exhilarating vibe to Disc One. Meanwhile, Linda Perry (who many will recognize as the composer of Christina's former #1 hit, \\"Beautiful\\") manages to recreate quite a replication of the music of the laissez-faire age. Nevertheless, it should be noted that while the motive behind the second disc is first and foremost to bring the sound of that era back to life, there is certainly much more than swing music and muffed mics. In fact, while Back To Basics is undeniably a throwback album, what ultimately separates it from everything else on the market is that it is much more than the simple covering of an era.  <br />   Disc One starts off with a simplistic, bass-knocking intro, as an announcer comes onto the record and introduces, in his words, \\"The one and only, there will never be another... Christina Aguilera.\\" Fitting that he would say this, for these words set the tempo to the rollercoaster ride of a classic that every listener will surely never forget. Fromthere, the throwback begins, as Aguilera belts, \\"I've waited for some time/ To get inside the minds/ Of every legend I've ever wanted to stand beside.\\" In fact, Aguilera pays lyical tribute to her idols twice, because on the head-bobbing \\"Back In The Day\\", where she endlessly boasts of how important it is for us to recognize the sounds of the past, she sings, \\"So breakout your Marvin Gaye, your Etta James, your Lady Day, and Coldtrain/ Turn up your 45's, bring back to life the sound and vibe of yesterday.\\"  Seemlessly flawless, track-after-track moves with ease, from the horn-blasting, throwback lead-single \\"Ain't No Other Man\\", to the catchy, hip-hop influenced and yet still retro jam \\"Slow Down Baby\\", to the soothing vocals of the beautiful ballad \\"Without You\\".  Disc One is such an invigorating replication of an often disregarded era of music in our society that it's almost as if Aguilera has created an all new genre of music, as the thirteen tracks should win over legions of fans both young and old.  <br />   Despite the lively, stimulating vibe of her upbeat records, perhaps Aguilera is at her best when she is not belting, but rather softly singing, thoroughly allowing her emotions to do the talking instead. Disc Two happens to showcase two of Aguilera's most emotional records ever recorded, \\"Hurt\\" and \\"Save Me From Myself\\". On the former, singing over the backdrop of a melancholy beat, she speaks of how she's so sorry for hurting and blaming a man she now desperately needs. On the latter, which is a pure dedication to her husband Jordan Bratman, Aguilera puts together perhaps the greatest vocal she has ever strung together. While it doesn't contain any of the signature belting we've become so accustomed to hearing from her, it's the softness of her voice that brings about a certain vulnerable tone that we've probably never seen from her, or better yet, maybe any artist over the past generation. <br />   Although \\"Hurt\\" and \\"Save Me From Myself\\" are the peak of Disc Two, one can be assured that Disc Two still has much more to offer. The infectious, swing-dance vibe emitted by \\"Candyman\\" should be an instant crowd pleaser, as should the jazz-club sexual nature of \\"Nasty Naughty Boy,\\" where Aguilera sultrily sings, \\"Ooh, there I go again/ I need a spankin' cause I've been bad/ So let my body do the talkin'/ I'll slip you that hot, sweet, sexy lovin'.\\" Finally,  \\"Trouble\\", undoubtedly the most authentic throwback on the album, should attract the curiousity of listeners everywhere, as the voice of Christina over a muffed mic and a static-laden backdrop should interest many.  <br />   Ever since Aguilera put out her self-titled debut, we've been patiently waiting for her to revive and refresh an industry that has quite frankly lost it's touch. In less than a decade, the former Mousketeer has delivered with an album that speaks volumes to her peers. Back To Basics is not only the best album to be released this year, it's the greatest release of the 21st century! <br />
B000002I97|5.0|I first saw John Prine on the old Phil Donahue show.  I immediately bought this record.  The date on this must be wrong because I know it came out in the 70's.  There is not a single track on this album I did not love.  I can say that on only a handful of CDs.  However, those other CDs cannot draw you in like Prine's stories.  In the 90's I got to see him perform in Orange County, CA.  Huge expectations - no disappointment.  Thanks John.
B000G759LW|5.0|There are few albums one highly anticipates, and when said album is actually purchased (at midnight, no less) little does one know that some expectations can be shattered...<br /><br />More like swiped into oblivion by a wrecking ball.<br /><br />Ladies and gentlemen and gentlemen who act like ladies, if you thought Miss Christina Aguilera-Bratman could NEVER top the masterful \\"Stripped,\\" please think again.<br /><br />\\"Back to Basics\\" is the most mesmerizing melting pot of jazz, soul, hip-hop, and sweeping Danny Elfman-esque harmonies (yes, you read that correctly) ever to fall upon listeners' ears.<br /><br />When was the last time you listened to an entire album all the way through without skipping a track? Don't even bother with Limewire. Get out the wallets and B-U-Y the physical copy at your nearest retailer. From the first song, Christina unleashes a vocal power that captivates you, preventing you from skipping to other songs before each song ends. A continuous playback of great tracks. It will definitely become a classic. To be honest, however, Christina's attempt at being retroactive with her music into the 50's era has failed. The album possesses only 3 or so songs which bring about the retro feel, two of which you already know, \\"Ain't No Other Man\\" and \\"I've Got Trouble\\". The music has a current appeal, but still makes for great listening nonetheless. So don't go expecting the album to be making you feel as if you're watching a black and white television set dripping in 30's, 40's and 50's sounds. Christina is still in 2006. She may have missed at the \\"retrospective\\" part, but she's got the great music on point like a pin! You won't get bored. Believe me.

I am a huge Shannen Doherty fan and can't wait to watch all these old episodes again and again. I never understood why it took so long to get this fabulous show on DVD. I can't wait until November...I am sooooo excited!

B000EULJLU|4.0|Boy does this band have a heck of a time living up to not only the expectations of their fans, but the critics too. That is very understandable since their 3 studio albums (excluding their debut EP) are considered to be masterpieces. \\"Undertow\\", \\"Aenima\\" and \\"Lateralus\\" rank as classic releases and cemented Tool's reputation as the best alternative metal band of all time. And the fact that Tool takes their sweet time putting albums out (an average of 4 years between CDs) only serves to enhance their reputation.  <br /> <br />Given such lofty standards, \\"10,000 Days\\" doesn't quite measure up. However, it still ranks as one of the best releases of 2006. The main complaint I have repeatedly seen from the so-called 'music critics' is that Tool has failed to make every second of this 78 minute opus perfect. GIVE ME A FREAKIN' BREAK! If there is a minimum of 45 to 50 minutes of great music on a CD, it has to be considered a success. 10K Days easily achieves this goal. Compare that to the critically acclaimed Jack White/Raconteurs debut: their album clocks out at 34 minutes! Would you pay $12.00 for what, no matter how good it might be, is essentially an EP? <br /> <br />But this latest Tool release does have a number of flaws that put it one category below their other full length albums. First off, no song can remain completely interesting for more than 11 minutes (the title track and \\"Rosetta Stoned\\"). The slow tempo intro of the title song goes on WAY too long. If these still excellent songs had been about 20% shorter, you could tack on an entire 1/2 a star to 10K Days' rating. Tool should have considered reducing the average length of the \\"real\\" songs on this CD just a bit. In the same vein, the experimental/filler tunes are extraneous, unnecessary and add nothing to the overall quality of the album.  <br /> <br />My biggest problem with this album is a complaint that I never thought I would utter. Maynard has become the weak link in this group of virtuosos and he appears to have \\"phoned in\\" his vocals on 10K Days. Keenan was, up until recently, hands down the BEST vocalist in modern rock and one of the greatest of all time. With his efforts on this album, his reputation will no doubt suffer (maybe he was distracted thinking about the next A Perfect Circle CD). I would rate Josh Homme, Serg Tankian, Wolfmother's Andrew Stockdale and few others above Maynard now. Compare the power and range he showed on \\"Undertow\\" to this release, and it is obvious that Keenan's vocal ability has fallen off a cliff. Its either that, or he just decided to put in a subpar effort. His vocal style on the first few minutes of \\"Rosetta Stoned\\" almost ruin a potentially world-class track. What a huge disappointment Maynard is on 10K Days. His only saving grace is that the lyrics on this CD are fairly compelling and interesting. <br /> <br />So, regardless of how mildly dissatisfying 10K Days is, Tool are still far and away the best band in rock and deserve comparisons with such all-time great groups as Zeppelin, Sabbath, Floyd, Yes, etc. The problem with rock critics is that they will listen to a release a few times over the span of a few days and decide its intrinsic quality and worth. You cannot be so superficial with a Tool release. It usually takes me a lot longer to get my head around all the subtleties and nuances of a Tool CD in comparison to most of the music I buy and this album is no different. All the \\"real\\" tracks on 10K Days are symphonic in nature, with complex movements and fascinating time signatures and changes. And the musicianship reestablishes the fact that Adam Jones, Justin Chancellor and Danny Carey are probably the most accomplished guitarist/bassist/drummer combination in rock music today. It is undeniable that Maynard Keenan's effort on 10K Days doesn't match his bandmates' achievements. Its a real shame since we probably won't be in line for another Tool release for quite some time (2010 if their history is used as a time frame). Hopefully those who have disparaged 10K Days will have the decency and common sense to give this album another chance and allow its intricacies and unparalled musicianship to change their feeble, shallow minds. They won't be dissappointed if they allow the subtle majesty of 10K Days to penetrate their jaded souls.
1400032717|5.0|I originally purchased this book because I have a nephew with Asperger's Syndrome, but took forever to read it.<br /><br />Let me say that I read quickly, but I finished this novel in one afternoon, it was that compelling and that good.<br /><br />Christopher Boone is 15, autistic, and a mathematics genius.  He doesn't understand humor or social interaction but still interacts with the world in his own unique way.  One of the things in the book that was the most touching, and untimately heartbreaking, is his relationship with his parents.  It is very realistic, including how the average parent copes (or does not cope) with an autistic child.  The way in which Christopher relates his Father's conversation with the schoolmaster is disjointed and very literal to Christopher, but we see it as a very plain example of his Father's love for him and his determination to do the best for his very different, very special son.<br /><br />I can't recommend this book enough.  Even if you don't have a motivation to read it from the autism angle, the novel itself is such a wonderful and wonderfully written story that anyone should enjoy it.

0679441018|4.0|Anne Rice's novels have always dealt with evil in relation to good and have always carried with them the massive Catholic undertones of her childhood.  This novel brings those questions, and in essence the very nature of our existence, into the forefront of her vision.<br /><br />I'll admit that the novel was hard to sink into in the beginning, but there came a point sometime in the middle where her vampire hero finds himself face to face with the devil as he recounts the tale of Genesis from what he claims to be the true story, and I found myself utterly enthralled.  It's an incredibly sympathetic view of the devil, painting him as an angel who could not comprehend the nature of suffering as it relates to God's vision.  But all the while, there exists a distrust amongst the two partners, as Lestat questions the impact of what he's been told and the implication of a devil who could be more pure of heart than his God.<br /><br />Some compare the dialogue between God and the devil in this novel to a debate between two philosophy majors.  I myself don't see the problem with that.  If anything it adds to the uncertainty of every piece of knowledge that we claim to possess, and nothing is for certain when the matter pertains to our Gods.  There's already tremendous fear and distrust in this world when it comes to the nature of God and the devil and their relationship to one another.  There's a grandiose horror in Rice's speculation that they know no more about the workings of this world than we do.  An experiment gone wrong, if you will.  Still, the characters are at all times long-winded and this book won't be a winner for everyone.  If you, like myself, already had an acute interest in both philosophy and more importantly, theology, I think you'll enjoy this book quite a bit.  Recommended to the interested for my part.
B000002JPA|5.0|In 1992, prog metal masterminds Dream Theater released their sophmore album Images And Words. It's by far their best and is arguably the best prog rock album of the whole 90s.<br /><br />Even though I don't do this often, I'll review the musicians before the album:<br /><br />James Labrie - Vocals. His vocals work perfectly with Dream Theater's music. You gotta love his falsetto. It works great with songs like Another Day and Take The Time.<br /><br />John Petrucci - Guitars. Honestly one of the greatest guitarists I've ever heard. He just proves that if you learn classical trained instead of.... modernly trained, you can do some crrrrrazy stuff with the guitar!!<br /><br />John Myung - Bass. Even though his bass may be hard to hear over John's wailing guitar solos, whenever you hear him, his work is VERY impressive (and this is coming from a bassist)<br /><br />Kevin Moore - Keyboards. An awesome keyboardist. He often trades off solos with John Petrucci in songs like Take The Time and Under A Glass Moon. He can make the keyboard sound angry and thrashy (like in Pull Me Under and Take The Time) to soft and soothing (like in Another Day and Surrounded). He also wrote DT's biggest hit Pull Me Under<br /><br />Mike Portony - Drums. Probably my 2nd favorite member of DT (Petrucci is #1). Even if you know nothing about percussion or rythm, you can easily tell that he's a killer drummer.... maybe even the best drummer of the new generation!<br /><br />Anyway, the album. Believe the hype! DT are masters of both their lyrics and their instruments. The way it usually works in I&W is that there is a heavy song, then a softer song, then a heavier song, etc. At times the songs may sound somewhat cheesy, but you can't deny what visionaries the 5 of them are. Even though DT is a prog metal band, if you compare this to their heavier albums like Awake and Train Of Thought, this is more of a prog rock album. But that doesn't take away any of the album's stength. Now onto the songs:<br /><br />Pull Me Under - 10/10 Easily the catchiest on the album, and DT's biggest hit to date. Pull Me Under is obviously about death, or dying, or thinking about death (\\"Every breath leaves me one lat to my last!\\"). It starts of real slow with an acoustic guitar and a piano, but quickly turns heavier. The chorus is also very catchy and memorable (\\"Pull me under! Pull Me Under! Pull Me under, I'm not afraid!\\"). One of the best off the album and one of DT's best songs even today.<br /><br />Another Day - 10/10 Why do people hate this song so much?! I thought it was beautiful (for lack of a better word). It was written by John Petrucci, and is about his father's stuggle with cancer. There's a great slow and wailing guitar solo by John and a memorable chorus (\\"You won't find it here, look another way. You won't find it here, so die another day!\\"). Also, you just gotta love the saxaphone throughout it.<br /><br />Take The Time - 8.5/10 Imagine that Slayer and Yes teamed up and made a song, because that's exactly what this song sounds like. While this song has a catchy chorus and meaningful lyrics, it gets a little silly at times, like before James sings the lyrics there's some crazy dialogue. And this is just my opinion, but I think the song should've just ended after the piano interlude. Still good though.<br /><br />Surrounded - 9/10 Probably the poppiest off the album. From what I hear, it's about the AIDs virus spreading. I like the piano/keyboard intro, and I prefer this songs over Take The Time, but a bit too poppy for my tastes.<br /><br />Metropolis - Pt 1 \\"The Mircale And The Sleeper\\" - 10/10 BAM! Easily the best song since Pull Me Under. It starts off with some percussion and a keyboard which both give the song a sort of a mystical feeling. But then it quickly becomes heavy with some great guitar riffs. It's basically the entire SFAM album in a nutshell. This is also where John Myung shines. Nothing needs to be said about this song that hasn't already beensaid.<br /><br />Under A Glass Moon - 10/10 One of the heaviest off the album, and in my opinion, the best. John performs his best solo and the whole album. And you gotta love the chorus: \\"Outside the soundness of you mind, bathing your soul in silver tears, beneath a blackened summer sky, praying for time to disappear!\\"<br /><br />Wait For Sleep - N/A Basically the intro to Learning To Live with James singing over Kevin's keyboard and piano. Most people tend to skip it, but if you pay attention to the lyrics, it's really a fascinating song.<br /><br />Learning To Live - 10/10 My 2nd favorite off the album (UAGM is #1), and the longest. According to popular belief, it's also about the aids virus, and the chorus probably represents that belief the most: \\"The way your heart sounds makes all the difference. It's what decides if you'll endure the pain we all feel. The way your heart beats makes all the diffrence, I'm learning to live. Here before is my soul I'm learning to live. I won't give up. 'Till I've no more to give.\\" An awesome way to end the album. Instead of just ending, the songs slowly fades away until you can't hear it.<br /><br />Well, that's my take and I&W. It's worth you $11, and was one of the best of 1992... dare I say even better than NIN's Broken and Alice In Chains Dirt?... I dare! Anyway, this album is recommended immensly and I doubt you'll be disappointed.<br /><br />Long live Dream Theater!!!st. John performs his best solo and the whole album. And you gotta love the chorus: \\"Outside the soundness of you mind, bathing your soul in silver tears, beneath a blackened summer sky, praying for time to disappear!\\"    Wait For Sleep - N/A Basically the intro to Learning To Live with James singing over Kevin's keyboard and piano. Most people tend to skip it, but if you pay attention to the lyrics, it's really a fascinating song.    Learning To Live - 10/10 My 2nd favorite off the album (UAGM is #1), and the longest. According to popular belief, it's also about the aids virus, and the chorus probably represents that belief the most: \\"The way your heart sounds makes all the difference. It's what decides if you'll endure the pain we all feel. The way your heart beats makes all the diffrence, I'm learning to live. Here before is my soul I'm learning to live. I won't give up. 'Till I've no more to give.\\" An awesome way to end the album. Instead of just ending, the songs slowly fades away until you can't hear it.    Well, that's my take and I&W. Anyway, this album is recommended immensly and I doubt you'll be disappointed.    Long live Dream Theater!!!

The combination of a larger-than-life Shakesphere-quoting hero and an Orwellian near future (or more apparent present) makes for fun and somewhat grim reading. This book is no where near as good a read as \\"1984\\" or \\"Fahrenheit 451,\\" but what it lacked in substance it made up for in style. B00005JOQS|5.0|***WARNING-CONTAINS SPOILERS***<br /><br />Superman . . . What does it mean to be \\"Super\\"?  What characteristics does it require to meet that standard?  What actions does one have to take in order to be considered \\"Super\\"?  Is it based on an individual's physical prowess and strength?  Or is it measured by one's intellect, wisdom, knowledge and understanding?  Perhaps it is one's spirituality setting moral/ethical codes and boundaries that determine it?  How do we define such an idea as \\"Super\\" be it man or woman?  And I'm sure that most everyone has already given up on the idea that your nationality has anything to do with this.  So, what is it?<br /><br />I personally am an avid comic fan of years past.  I can recollect my childhood on through adolescence buried in one comic or another.  The pages that unfolded before me contained all the magic and idealism of right vs. wrong/heroes vs. villain splashed in all their Herculean, muscle-popping glory.  Back then these pages were filled with social and moral uprightness along with the consequences of living unjust and wicked (even if it always required the heroes to pummel the justice back into the unjust).  Movies and media followed suit with the 80's blasting \\"bad guys\\" away in the most extreme of extreme prejudices.  Rocky, Rambo, Indiana, the original Superman films, Star Wars all embodied these characteristics.  These stories told classic heroes tales, the heroes tales that are easily traced back to classic Greek mythology.  These were simple to understand: do good in spite of the circumstance and in the end you win (or at least the world wins by not being overthrown, enslaved, or just blown up) or do evil and you will be stopped one way or another.  Personally, I believe OUR WORLD today needs to return to these basic, simple principles.<br /><br />Now, finally the movie-Superman Returns does just this.  It demonstrates that in a world full of crisis, turmoil, distrust, hatred, death, war, violence, racial/ethnic/religious prejudice, pain, depression, over-sexualization, rampant drug-use, lack of self-responsibility, over-fascination for body modification, low morals, low self-esteem, low-education levels, and low expectations of ourselves and our futures that we absolutely need to look for a \\"Super\\"-anybody to help point us in the right direction.<br /><br />Brandon Routh's performance is dead-on to the late, legendary Christopher Reeve's portrayal of the \\"Super\\"-boy scout.  His presentation of sacrificing Superman's personal love of Lois Lane to her current love-interest is a clear act of selflessness.  By putting aside his own personal feelings and acknowledging that James Marsden's character, Richard White, is a good man through the slightest glance Superman gives him; thus handing over the care and upbringing of his greatest love along with his own son.  By today's standards he should fight for his love and ignore the emotional ramifications that this would pose on Lois in order to hide such an enormous burden as well as their son having that strained weight of discovering the father he believed he has in not really his father and not to mention that this would most certainly place those he loves most in constant danger from anyone who wishes to destroy Superman.  The film also demonstrates this same selflessness in Superman's decision to prevent Metropolis's destruction before going to rescue Lois Lane.  He must put aside his personal feelings for the cause of the greater good.  Unfortunately, most people today lack the courage to make such hard decisions instead opting to ignore problems hoping that eventually they'll just vanish.  Sadly, that never happens.  And once again the movie establishes what is \\"Super\\" by showing that in spite of the fact that Superman loses his super powers and is beaten, kicked, humiliated, and stabbed in the lower-back with a 6 inch piece of kryptonite that is broken off to be left inside his body he still fights to get up, never quittingto stand up for what is right.  The film then represents what is \\"Super\\" by demonstrating Superman's selflessness once again after being rescued having the piece of kryptonite removed out of his apparent kidney by Lois, Jason (their son) and Richard that he immediately chooses to go back to face Lex Luthor in order to save \\"billions\\" even with his impending death most likely ahead.  I will not mention any other spoilers from here, but instead go back to my original questions?<br /><br />So, where are the \\"Super's\\" of today that embody this?  I believe many are fighting hard for my 1st Amendment right as I type this over in Iraq and across the world.  There are also many who do their best to maintain order, defend civilians at the potential risk to themselves and bring peace to our communities.  These civil servants do so much and yet we as a free speech society, who live in an era that has knowledge at our fingertips and proclaimed equality out of our mouths, turn a blind eye when our neighbor is in need.  Or we just say to ourselves \\"Oh, too bad for them, hopefully someone will do something about it.\\"  Why do we always have to put \\"it\\" on someone else?  When will we return to having a standard of justice, moral rightness, friendliness and samaritanism that waves proudly and boldly for others to see?  I believe that when that happens that others will begin to join in and before you know the world will not need a Superman, because it already has a Supereveryone.what is right.
